Sure! To compare two columns in a DataFrame, you can use the `matplotlib` library for plotting. Below is an example code snippet that demonstrates how to create a bar chart comparing two columns:

```python
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Sample data
data = {
    'Category': ['A', 'B', 'C', 'D'],
    'Values1': [10, 24, 30, 15],
    'Values2': [12, 20, 28, 16]
}

# Create DataFrame
df = pd.DataFrame(data)

# Set the figure size
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))

# Create a bar chart for each column
bar_width = 0.35
index = range(len(df['Category']))

bars1 = plt.bar(index, df['Values1'], bar_width, label='Values1', color='b')
bars2 = plt.bar([i + bar_width for i in index], df['Values2'], bar_width, label='Values2', color='r')

# Add some text for labels, title and axes ticks
plt.xlabel('Category')
plt.ylabel('Values')
plt.title('Comparison of Values1 and Values2')
plt.xticks([i + bar_width / 2 for i in index], df['Category'])
plt.legend()

# Show the plot
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()
```

This code will create a bar chart comparing `Values1` and `Values2` across different categories. You can customize the plot further by changing the colors, adding more columns, or choosing a different type of plot like line plots, scatter plots, etc.

Make sure you have `matplotlib` installed in your environment:
```sh
pip install matplotlib
```

If you want to use a different type of plot, feel free to modify the code accordingly. For example, for a line plot:

```python
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
plt.plot(df['Category'], df['Values1'], marker='o', label='Values1', color='b')
plt.plot(df['Category'], df['Values2'], marker='o', label='Values2', color='r')

plt.xlabel('Category')
plt.ylabel('Values')
plt.title('Comparison of Values1 and Values2')
plt.legend()

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()
```

This will create a line plot to compare the two columns.
